NAŠI KOSMATINCI: Kakšno je delo veterinarja
03 Nov 2019, 06:02 by Nataša Tozon

Doktorji veterinarske medicine in vsi, ki nas pri našem delu obkrožajo, se pogosto sprašujemo, kako to, da nas lastniki naših pacientov tako slabo razumejo in tako kritično ocenjujejo naše delo. Je res mogoče, da tako slabo poznajo naše delo, ki je zelo podobno delu zdravnikov, dr. medicine?

Zdi se, da številne bolj ali manj kakovostne oddaje, ki poskušajo prikazati delo veterinarja, ne koristijo najbolj. Včasih se zdi celo nasprotno. V poplavi resničnostnih šovov so tudi tiste, v katerih nastopajo taki in drugačni “junaki”, “reševalci” in “heroji”. So to res pravi prikazi vsakdana veterinarja?
Tudi v stroki, kot je veterinarska medicina, ki zahteva celovit pristop ne le do bolne živali, ampak tudi do njegovega lastnika, smo priča splošni potrošniški mrzlici, v kateri ni prostora za umirjen razgovor, premislek in čas za izbiro najboljše poti do cilja. Danes pričakujemo odgovor takoj in zdaj, temu pa prepogosto v isti sapi sledi vprašanje o popustu na ceno našega dela, saj smo vendar ljubitelji živali?!
Delo veterinarja je poslanstvo, ki ga ne moremo ovrednotiti z denarjem. Pomeni način življenja, ki zahteva dolgoletni študij, vseživljenjsko izobraževanje, poleg katerega se večinoma vsak zase bori z vplivi kroničnega stresa in za preprečevanje katerega praktično ne skrbi nihče.
Da, tudi mi imamo urgentno službo, ki jo pogovorno imenujemo dežurstvo. Za delo v dežurni službi, vsaj na Kliniki za male živali Veterinarske fakultete, vsakega mladega kolega najprej strokovno usposobimo. Prve korake opravlja v družbi starejšega kolega, pri čemer imata v vsakem trenutku še podporno ekipo v pripravljenosti. Dežurno službo tako zagotavljamo nepretrgoma 24 ur na dan 365 dni v letu. Naloga dežurnega veterinarja je primarna oskrba pacienta, pogovor z lastnikom, izvedba najnujnejše diagnostike. Po presoji se dežurnemu veterinarju pridruži strokovnjak za slikovno diagnostiko, v primeru nujnih kirurških posegov pa tudi anesteziolog in kirurg.
Ker smo izobraževalna inštitucija, ki vzgaja nove rodove dr. veterinarske medicine, so pri našem delu prisotni tudi študentje 6. letnika veterine, ki so že zaključili celotno teoretično izobraževanje in si v zadnjem letniku izobraževanja pridobivajo praktične izkušnje na vseh podpodročjih kliničnega dela. Njihovo izobraževanje je tudi neprecenljiva pomoč nam veterinarjem, saj so to bodoči kolegi, ki so tik pred samostojno poklicno potjo in so si tudi do zadnjega letnika študija pridobili številne praktične izkušnje. Hkrati smo kot pedagogi dolžni zagotoviti njihovo vsestransko strokovnost.
In ko se ponovno vrnem k razmisleku o delu v dežurni službi. Veliko primerov pravzaprav ni resnično urgentnih, a jih po pravilu obravnavamo resno. Zgodi pa se, da gre za urgence, in ni hujšega, kot da se ti zgodi več urgentnih primerov hkrati, kot bi šlo za masovno nesrečo. V hipu je potrebno določiti prednostno obravnavo in najprej reševati življenja. Četudi zelo dobro razumemo skrbi lastnika, je najbrž povsem razumljivo, da ni časa za pogovor, oskrba pa praviloma zahteva celega človeka, ne glede na izkušnje. Saj ima najbrž skoraj vsak med vami že izkušnjo obiska urgence za ljudi.
V povsem novih urgentnih centrih paciente razvrstijo po nujnosti obravnave. Manj nujni čakajo v čakalnici, najnujnejši pa so sprejeti v takojšnjo obravnavo. Svojci, ki pacienta spremljajo do urgence, v kolikor ni pripeljan z rešilcem, bolnika prepustijo zdravnikom in zaskrbljeni čakajo na vsako informacijo. Nikomur ne pride na misel, da bi svojca spremljal med postopkom obravnave, kaj šele na primer oživljanja.
Zdravniki morajo opraviti svoje delo zbrano in po svojih najboljših močeh. Ko je najhuje mimo, ne glede na izid, je čas za pogovore. In kako to, da se nekaterim lastnikom hudo bolne živali, ki je morda celo življenjsko ogrožena, zdi nujno spremljanje celotnega postopka? Nemalo je tudi tistih, ki se pritožijo nad odnosom, nesprejemljivo, nezadostno ali pomanjkljivo komunikacijo.
Tudi doktorji veterinarske medicine si želimo, da bi razumeli in zaupali našemu delu, da bi naše delo cenili. Verjemite, da je največja nagrada in priznanje, da smo pacientu pomagali in če se le da zdravega odpustili v domačo oskrbo. In težko nam je, ko se izteče slabo. Hkrati se moramo vsi zavedati minljivosti življenja in so trenutki, ko se nam kdaj pa kdaj vsaj za trenutek “zruši svet”.
Delo veterinarja je poslanstvo, ki ga ne moremo ovrednotiti z denarjem. Pomeni način življenja, ki zahteva dolgoletni študij, vseživljenjsko izobraževanje, poleg katerega se večinoma vsak zase bori z vplivi kroničnega stresa in za preprečevanje katerega praktično ne skrbi nihče. Podatek, da so veterinarji med najbolj rizičnimi poklici za samomor, je sam po sebi dovolj zgovoren. In le redko slišim kolege, da bi zaradi večinoma skromnega plačila razmišljali o zamenjavi poklica. Številni mladi kolegi danes po letih izobraževanja svoje delo opravljajo za minimalno plačo, in ne tako redko, dežurstvo opravljajo brezplačno ali za minimalno plačilo.
Prof. dr. Nataša Tozon, predstojnica Klinike za male živali na Veterinarski fakulteti v Ljubljani

OUR COSMATINES: What a vet's job is
03 Nov 2019, 06:02 by Natasha Tozon

Doctors of veterinary medicine and everyone around us often wonder how it is that our patients' owners understand us so poorly and so critically evaluate our work. It is possible that they know so poorly our work, which is very similar to the work of doctors, dr. medicine?

Many of the more or less high quality shows that try to show the vet's work don't seem to benefit the most. At times it seems even the opposite. The flood of reality shows also include those featuring such and other "heroes", "rescuers" and "heroes". Are these really real life vets?
Even in a profession such as veterinary medicine, which requires a holistic approach not only to the sick animal but also to its owner, we are witnessing a general consumer fever that lacks space for calm conversation, reflection and time to choose the best path to the goal. Today we expect an answer now and now, and all too often the same question is followed by the question of discounting the price of our work, since we are animal lovers ?!
The job of a vet is a mission that cannot be evaluated with money. It is a way of life that requires years of study, lifelong learning, in addition to which most people struggle with the effects of chronic stress for themselves, and that is prevented by virtually no one.
Yes, we also have an emergency service, which we call on call. Every young colleague is first qualified to work in the on-call service, at least at the Animal Clinic of the Veterinary Faculty. She takes the first steps in the company of an older colleague, with their support team on standby at all times. The on-call service is thus provided 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. The on-duty veterinarian has the task of primary care for the patient, talking to the owner, performing the most urgent diagnostics. At the discretion, the imaging veterinarian is joined by a specialist in imaging diagnostics and, in the case of emergency surgery, an anesthesiologist and surgeon.
Because we are an educational institution that breeds new generations of dr. veterinary medicine, in our work there are also students of 6th year of veterinary medicine who have already completed the entire theoretical education and are gaining practical experience in all sub-fields of clinical work in the last year of education. Their education is also an invaluable aid to us veterinarians, as they are future colleagues who are just before their independent careers and have gained many practical experience by the last year of their studies. At the same time, we, as educators, have a responsibility to ensure their versatile expertise.
And when I go back to thinking about working on duty. Many cases are not really urgent, but as a rule they are taken seriously. But it just happens to be an emergency, and it's no worse than having multiple emergencies happen at the same time as a massive accident. It is important to prioritize and save lives first. Even though we understand the owner's concerns very well, it is probably quite understandable that there is no time to talk, and care generally requires the whole person, regardless of experience. Almost every one of you already has the experience of visiting emergency rooms for people.
At brand new emergency centers, patients are sorted by urgency. The less urgent are waiting in the waiting room, and the most urgent are accepted for immediate consideration. Relatives who accompany the patient to the emergency room, unless accompanied by an ambulance, leave the patient to the doctors and wait for any information they need. It never occurs to anyone to accompany a relative during the treatment process, let alone for example resuscitation.
Doctors should do their job collectively and to the best of their ability. When the worst is over, regardless of the outcome, it's time to talk. And how does it feel necessary for some owners of a seriously ill animal, who may even be at risk of life, to monitor the whole process? There are also many who complain about the relationship, unacceptable, insufficient or inadequate communication.
Veterinary doctors also want us to understand and trust our work to value our work. Believe that the greatest reward and recognition is that we have helped the patient and, if they are healthy, have been discharged into home care. And it's hard for us when it comes out bad. At the same time, we must all be aware of the transience of life, and there are times when the world “crashes” for us at least for a moment.
The job of a vet is a mission that cannot be evaluated with money. It is a way of life that requires years of study, lifelong learning, in addition to which most people struggle with the effects of chronic stress for themselves, and that is prevented by virtually no one. The fact that veterinarians are among the most risky professions for suicide is self-explanatory enough. And rarely do I hear my colleagues think about changing jobs for the most part, because of their modest pay. Many young colleagues today, after years of education, do their jobs for a minimum wage, and not infrequently, they are on duty for free or for a minimum wage.
Prof. dr. dr. Nataša Tozon, Head of the Small Animal Clinic at the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine in Ljubljana
